content: Hi everyone, I am trying to get backdrop on my bluehost shared server. I created the database using cpanel as instructed, but when I unzip the download I get a 500 error. Are there any known issues with bluehost or the installation process in general?

Hi, Chuck Tilbury. Welcome to the Backdrop CMS community on Zulip. I'm your friendly neighborhood Dragonbot. Try '@Dragonbot help' for a list of things I can help you with. There are lots of friendly humans that hang around here, so please feel free to ask questions.

Here is a short (3 min) video to help you navigate Zulip. https://youtu.be/DN8YL2MrsSU
@Chuck Tilbury - Welcome. Can you point us at which instructions you are using or provide any additional information.

NOTE: You are welcome to ask questions here, but the forum is also a good place.
https://forum.backdropcms.org/

Hey @Chuck Tilbury ...there's this previously-reported issue in our queue: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/2967 ...turns out that switching to a newer version of php (which Bluehost apparently does support) fixed the issue. What php version have you configured your site to run on?

Backdrop's PHP version requirement prevents it from being installed on Bluehost · Issue #2967 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Describe your issue or idea When trying to deploy a backdrop site to Bluehost, I encountered this error: Your PHP installation is too old. Backdrop CMS requires at least PHP 5.3.2. See the System R...
No problems on Bluehost so far

Here is a link to the instructions I am using. https://backdropcms.org/installation

It's just what I found on the web site. I downloaded to the zip file and unziped it. That made a directory called backdrop/. I moved all of the files and directories up one level so that the index.php file is in the right place. I think there is probably some configuration issue, but I don't really know where to start.

The version of PHP is 7.3.12

Is there a way to see the actual error that happened?
@Chuck Tilbury , if you would like to do a screen share. I'd be willing to look at what your doing and see if I can offer any advice.

Another option would be to create a forum post where you list in detail what steps you are taking. The more information we have the more likely we can offer advice. Things like, what path are you using to access the new BackdropCMS site and how did you configure that path (or what instructions does Bluehost give you about where to find your site).

Thanks @StPaulTim That's kind of a problem, though. My internet connection <suks> I live in the sticks so all I have is satellite. Ping times are always near a second or so. Ssh to the server is... fun...

As you can tell, I don't really know how to do this. I am a C and Python guy mostly. Web sites are a new thing for me.
No problem. It was just a thought. I'd love to help you and also figure out if there is something we can add to those instructions that might help the next person.
Are you sure that you have the right path to your site. The correct default URL?
You could put a simple test.html file on the server and be sure that you can access that. Because if you can't access a simple .html file, you would be able to start the install process.

That having been said, I am following the instructions on the web site. I created the database with no troubles. That seems okay. It should be possible to turn on error display. I found this elsewhere:

error_reporting(E_ERROR | E_WARNING | E_PARSE | E_NOTICE);
ini_set('display_errors', TRUE);
ini_set('display_startup_errors', TRUE);

I take it that can be added to the index.php.
Well, I don't think you should ever have to edit or add anything to the index.php file. That is part of core and you shouldn't have to change it.
Sometimes it's necessary to edit the .htaccess file.
The site is boskycallow.org. I am setting up a blog there. I put a simple index.html, which appears as expected.
OK, good
ah. the .htaccess....
That would be in the ~/public_html/ direcory, correct?
I have other web sites defined for this shared server as well.
My production site is whistlemaker.com
Well, I'm not an .htaccess expert and sometimes there are more than one.
There is one included in BackdropCMS core that should be in the root directory of your site.
There are situations in which you need to edit that file. Having multiple sites on the same share hosting account is a situation in which you might need to make changes there.

There are just 3 lines in it:

<IfModule mime_module>
AddHandler application/x-httpd-ea-php73 .php .php7 .phtml
</IfModule>
no. I lied. There are a dozen or more lines.
1) I assume that the test.html file you placed you pointed me at is in /public_html/index.html ??
No. It's in ~/public_html/boskycallow/
2) OK, just to be clear, that is also where you put the index.php file for Backdrop CMS, correct?
yes.
OK, good

Chuck Tilbury said:

There are just 3 lines in it:

<IfModule mime_module>
AddHandler application/x-httpd-ea-php73 .php .php7 .phtml
</IfModule>

Which file is this?
~/public_html/.htaccess1

This is what the official backdropcms .htaccess file should look like:
https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop/blob/1.x/.htaccess

backdrop/backdrop
Backdrop core code repository. Contribute to backdrop/backdrop development by creating an account on GitHub.
Yeah, I don't about the .htaccess file provided by Bluehost. I can't help you there. The one I am talking about is in Backdrop CMS root.
I recommend you read through the settings.php file. There might be something you have to fix there.
I need to digest that a little. It sounds like I need to call bluehost again. Looking at the existing file, there are references to whistlemaker/index.php
So it follows that I would need to add the new site as well.
Was the code for Backdrop CMS provided by Bluehost or downloaded from BackdropCMS.org?
From BackdropCMS.org.
OK. I'm not clear where the references to whistlemaker.index.php are, but that might be something to look into.
whistlemaker.com is an existing site on this server. It's up and running (last time I checked ) :grinning:
DOH! It's not up! I have to go and fix that right now.
Fixed it.

I feel fairly confident is saying the following things.
1) If you can't even get to the install screen of Backdrop CMS - then the database isn't your problem (at least not yet).
2) The only two files you MIGHT have to edit would be .htaccess or settings.php (I would start by looking at settings.php).
3) You might considering googling "problems install Drupal 7 on Bluehost" - since the process for install Backdrop CMS should be very similar to install Drupal 7 and there might be more documentation around Drupal 7 than there is for Backdrop.
I need to talk to the folks at bluehost before I really make a mess.
Is there a pointer to some minimum requirements for the setup.php file?
It sounds to me like the problem is that your properly accessing the index.php file and once you figure that out, you should be in good (or better) shape.
agree. I think I need to add an entry to the .htaccess file.
Maybe Bluehost can help you with that.
I think that bluehost support can help me with that.
ya. I am going to go and ping them now. Would it be helpful if I post the results here when I am done?
Good luck. Let us know what you find.
Thanks. Will do.
It would be most helpful if you posted them in the forum, because they are easier to find there. But, a quick update here is also good.
Okay. I just created a login there. Thanks. I really appreciate you taking some time to help me.

@Chuck Tilbury - I see someone had a similar problem and never got help. If you find any answers, post them in response to that issue.
https://forum.backdropcms.org/forum/http-500-error
You probably saw that already!
The problem was file permissions. I don't know what the default was, but the correct permissions are 644.
The .htaccess file was not touched.
I should have thought of that! Congratulations.

Will you have time to update the forum post, or should I?
https://forum.backdropcms.org/forum/http-500-error

me too.... <<sigh>>
How many times have that jumped up and bit my butt....
I will do it.

After creating a php database, I get:
Failed to connect to your database server. The server reports the following message: Access denied for user 'sarvasri'@'localhost' (using password: YES).

Is the database server running on 127.0.0.1?
Is sardb the correct database name?
Are the username and password correct?

The database is not at 127... instead it's at %
This topic was moved here from #Community Chat (other topics) > Welcome by klonos

There doesn't seem to be a way to change % (the default Host Name in MAMP) to localhost. The instructions for installing Backdrop should explicitly require "localhost" since % (the default) doesn't seem to work. There is no way to change the Host Name in PHPMyAdmin that I can find, so I have to delete the database and start all over. Apparently bad instructions for how to install BackDrop on your computer. This should be corrected in the documentation.

Also, deleting the old database doesn't work. I deleted the database and created a new one with the same name. It automatically put % as the Host Name for me as the user. I don't know how to fix this problem.
Where are you seeing the % ? During the install on the "Database configuration" page?

When I add the user, I must input user name, Host Name, etc.
I tried using 127.0.0.1 and localhost in addition to the default %
Nothing works so far, I can't get past the same error message.

As I understand it, I must create a database ahead of running BackDrop. So I created an empty database with PHPMyAdmin. Then I need a user and a password for BackDrop to use the database. In creating the User and Password there are other fields that have default values. For Host Name, % is the default. Searching the web, % is not a substitute for either localhost or 127.0.0.1 so I don't know how or why % is the default. The instructions at https://backdropcms.org/installation are inadequate. For a first time user, they are impossible.
I'm not sure why you have a % there. I don't recall ever seeing that before. Maybe MAMP is helping you out, and unfortunately, I know nothing about MAMP.
@Sarvasri perhaps if you posted a screenshot, it would help us understand better and be able to help you out.

@Sarvasri This % is a placeholder for "from any host". Here's a screenshot from phpmyadmin:
screenshot-pma.png

That % for sure isn't causing the problem. It's rather a problem with your mysql setup.
One thing that comes to my mind: what's the "Authentication Plugin" setting?

And I suppose you really made sure there's no typo in your username/password credentials.

I'm not sure what you mean by "Authentication Plugin" but when I created the database I gave myself all privileges.
When I came back to the database today in phpMyAdmin, I had a Note from the software in yellow that said, "Note: phpMyAdmin gets the users’ privileges directly from MySQL’s privilege tables. The content of these tables may differ from the privileges the server uses, if they have been changed manually. In this case, you should reload the privileges before you continue." I don't understand this and don't know how I would reload privileges.
Also, I don't know which user Host Name to use whether %, 127..., or localhost. I would like to be consistent because I have 4 or 5 websites to create or convert from Drupal 7.

If using % for "Any host" would help me later when I want to move the BackDrop site to my internet host, then that would be preferable. % is the default in MAMP. I don't yet know how to move a finished site to a host later, so whatever I can do now to prevent problems is a good thing to do.

I'm starting over from scratch. I deleted all users and dropped the database. The instructions say, "Create a database, and make a note of the database name and hostname (usually localhost)." I can create a database -- in doing so, I can give it a name, I can allow the default for Collation which is utf_general_ci, but I cannot choose a hostname. It just creates the database. Then phpMyAdmin takes me to the Structure tab where I can "Create table." I presume that BackDrop will create all the tables I need. So now I go to the Privileges Tab where I can create a new user for the database. NOWHERE in the process was there an opportunity to "note the database name and hostname." I can note the database name only. No option to note a hostname. I could NOT choose a host or hostname during the database creation.

When you input the database credentials in the Backdrop installer form, you use localhost. That % is just a placeholder for the _database_ - that has nothing to do with Backdrop. So: localhost.

The database has no credentials, it's the _database user_ who has. So you create a user first - and I'd recommend to do it all in one step (db and user). That's easy in phpmyadmin. Please check the documentation of phpmyadmin.

I finally got a BackDrop installation to work.
Here's the problem. You can't just enter your user name and password for the database. You can't just set "localhost" as your user host name.
You have to click on Advanced Options and check on the database location, in my case the database location was set at 127.0.0.1 whereas my user login host name was set, as recommended, to "localhost" -- So it would not work. The Advanced options are invisible until you click on them. This costs me several days. Including a screenshot would not have helped. Advanced options were not visible.

Glad you have worked this out @Sarvasri but sorry it had to take you that long. Do we have documentation on that that's outdated or missing details? I could update it to include your findings, so that others don't waste time in the future.

Yes, at https://backdropcms.org/installation the instructions are not correct. Under "Create the MySQL database" is says "Create a database, and make a note of the database name and hostname (usually localhost).

You can create a database, but in some phpMyAdmins (I'm using MAMP) you don't see the hostname when you create the database. I spent a long time looking for it and couldn't find it. Frustrating. You assign a host name when you create a USER for the database.

But that doesn't work right either, because you can get it wrong. In MAMP, I had to click on the Advanced Option to see where the database was created. If I didn't select the same host name in my user setup, then I couldn't log in to BackDrop because the user or password was wrong. The database was created at 127.0.0.1 but I had selected "localhost" for the user. In the Advanced option, I could change it to "localhost" and then everything worked. It took me a LONG time to discover the problem by clicking around.

Thanks @Sarvasri ...I think that all your hard work and effort trying to figure out what worked in the end, deserves to be either in a subsection of that online documentation (MAMP-specific instructions that is), or in the forum ...or both.

To be honest and blunt (and I mean this in the nicest way possible :smile: ) the instructions for creating the database is very poor and disjointed. The instructions, from what I've read, assume you already know how to create a database... They haven't been written with the novice in mind. For example, where it says "Create a database and make a note of the database name and hostname (usually localhost)." "The database name and localhost" bit shouldn't really be in the same sentence and it does seem to imply you will get the settings from phpMyAdmin or similar. A good proportion of shared hosting will use "localhost" and if you are using it on LAMP or WAMP or MAMP then it will also probably be "Localhost" but some hosting providers do use a separate system for hosting the database server... for example the hosting company I use, you have to specify the server similar to this... "shareddb1a.hosting.stackcp.net".

So, should the instructions be expanded (I don't mind helping) or should the instructions be changed to point to places on the internet where instructions have already been created for the different systems?

And, where a certain level of knowledge is expected, that should be stated... for example, "The following instructions will assume you already know how to create a database with the correct privileges to be able to install BackdropCMS" type of thing.

Hope this helps.

@Sarvasri, it is MAMP specific. I use Linux (CentOS) servers (not local) and everything works correctly according to the directions. They are based on the D6/D7 directions and we've been doing this 20 years with various flavors of UNIX and not run into an issue. But good to know for MAMP.

@klonos - MAMP is pretty specific to Windows and is a bit wicky (odd) to work with. It absolutely does not work the same as the Linux/ Unix, (just like everything else on Windows in my personal opinion). They make a macOS version for some ungodly reason too, but I've never touched that, Linux/UNIX works fine and MySQL server can be installed on a mac as is. The Linux/Unix version is standard and that's what Drupal was developed on. I think the original installation instructions from Drupal (and that Backdrop is also based on) were written in German for Linux systems and then translated. They also do presume some basic Unix / Database knowledge, as well as some basic programming skills. I only go as far back as D5 and we really only started focusing on Drupal as an agency when 6 came out. We only had a few D5 sites. It was easier for my partner to do static at that point. D6 was really a turning point for us. The basic installation really hasn't changed. I don't know what it was like before that. Wordpress also installs pretty much the same way. My conclusion is that it's really the MAMP portion that is different and probably very poorly documented because it's such a small user base. ( https://www.mamp.info/en/windows/ ). I've installed MySQL server and Drupal locally with no problems, without MAMP, FYI, when I needed to test something out.

I'm an ex-Windows person, only using Mac the past 3-4 years. I started my web dev attempts as back as 2001 (using Dreamweaver :sweat_smile:) and then started playing with Drupal in 2006-2007. I've always used XAMPP as my AMP stack and it never failed me ...not even when I switched to Mac. ...the Tech Lead that was mentoring me in the agency that offered me the Drupal support engineer job in 2017 was using https://github.com/beetboxvm/beetbox ...that has also served me very well, but the person that maintained it moved to http://amazee.io (which are behind https://github.com/amazeeio/lagoon the infrastructure used by the GovCMS Platform). Since I use that platform day-to-day, I have switched to Docker + https://github.com/amazeeio/pygmy + https://github.com/ahoy-cli/ahoy (all enterprise-orientated tools) which also serve me well for my day job ...but when working with Backdrop, I wanted something simple yet robust ...I fiddled with https://www.ddev.com/ddev-local for a brief period, which I liked but had some issues with ...when @Geoff St. Pierre (serundeputy) mentioned that the agency he works for are behind https://lando.dev, I switched to that and never looked back since (mainly because Geoff was very promptly answering questions and solved any hiccup people in the Backdrop community mentioned). ...I hope that all this information helps, but in the end, which tool people use for their job is based on their personal preferences and experience with it + it seems that mileage varies most of the times :sweat_smile:

@Sarvasri I have found that the easiest way to share documentation via Google docs or an Etherpad instance (https://pad.riseup.net is one such service) ...but any way that you are comfortable with would do (even uploading a .pdf somewhere and sharing the link). ...another option is that if you have an account in backdropcms.org, you could create a documentation page.
